turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: No.
Your -- on -- in this case?

turn.speaker: milton_a_rudin
turn.label: Mr. Milton A. Rudin

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: --Because -- because the -- this -- because the testamentary disposition deter -- controls the whole disposition.

turn.speaker: milton_a_rudin
turn.label: Mr. Milton A. Rudin
turn.text: Steps three came in beforehand, yes Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well that, suppose he had made his next of kin the beneficiary.

turn.speaker: milton_a_rudin
turn.label: Mr. Milton A. Rudin
turn.text: I believe that there's --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Would that make any difference?

turn.speaker: milton_a_rudin
turn.label: Mr. Milton A. Rudin
turn.text: I don't -- it might have made a difference but not as a matter of copyright law.
It would've made a difference based on the instrument, the matter of general law interpreting --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I'm talking about --

turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker

turn.text: What's the difference between this and in the other (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: milton_a_rudin
turn.label: Mr. Milton A. Rudin
turn.text: Well, let me -- let me illustrate it directly with copyright law, Mr. Justice Whitaker.

He lives it to his executor, the same manner that he could have assigned it to him.
And the executor takes that right in the same manner that he might also take Black Acre or 100 shares of General Motors at the (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Any asset.

turn.speaker: milton_a_rudin
turn.label: Mr. Milton A. Rudin
turn.text: Any asset.

turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Revisable asset?

turn.speaker: milton_a_rudin
turn.label: Mr. Milton A. Rudin
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But -- but isn't -- isn't that what the whole litigation is about?

turn.speaker: milton_a_rudin
turn.label: Mr. Milton A. Rudin

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- maybe what you just said.

turn.speaker: milton_a_rudin

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- discussions.

turn.speaker: milton_a_rudin
turn.label: Mr. Milton A. Rudin
turn.text: And we respectfully submit that if Congress, if you look at the purpose, if -- if you have the widow and children first, why did the Congress say, executor and not at -- to his estate or not to his executor's administrators or assigns if they intended that the third class as I put it, was of the same nature of the first class that the only thing that stopped it from merging together was the second class, the widow or children.

I submit -- I admit the Court has to decide it, that's why we're here but I respectfully urge upon the Court that the construction must be that because of the intervening class and because of the schedule of rights.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I -- I must say I can -- I can understand why you're here and the argument your making but I can't understand that I'm on the logic of compulsion to hold that because Congress said we are going to protect the man's wife and his children, but we also give him the right to cut them off if he wants that and we also give him the right respecting that to make such other disposition as he wants to make, cut out all his next of kin and everybody else.
That's true as far as --

turn.speaker: milton_a_rudin

turn.text: Well --

turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter

turn.speaker: milton_a_rudin

turn.speaker: milton_a_rudin

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter

turn.speaker: milton_a_rudin

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black

turn.text: Well, Mr. Rudin.

turn.text: Isn't that right?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I gather your position is you may defend the objections in your favor below in any grounds you can without regard to the questions of --

turn.speaker: milton_a_rudin
turn.label: Mr. Milton A. Rudin
turn.text: Well, certainly we did but we don't think we have to defend it because he hasn't raised it.
It's brought in here on the sole issue we believe as to whether the assignment of the right in step one as I call it, defeated the exercise of the rights under step three.
And we say that that's -- there are no different classes, they're all the same right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You can defend a judgement on any ground with reference to the -- to the decision of the case if you can't bring in on the questions presented, another issue not in the case.

turn.speaker: milton_a_rudin
turn.label: Mr. Milton A. Rudin
turn.text: I don't want to make my task any harder --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Alright.

turn.speaker: milton_a_rudin
turn.label: Mr. Milton A. Rudin
turn.text: -- than it is, Your Honor.
[Laughs]I believe that, that's it.
I'd like to briefly refer to Fox versus Knowles which was cited for a proposition, I didn't understand to hold.
It very simply held that the executor has the rights and renew which is independent of the author's right.
It's -- it's of significance here prior to the Fox case.
There seem to be the thought that the executor was in the statute only exercise the right of renewal if the author made it into the 28th year but he didn't exercise the right during the 28th year.
And therefore, the executor had a limited function in the statute.
In Fox case held otherwise and said that it was a separate and independent right.
Referring to what is exercising the same right of the decedent, it didn't mean the same grant of right under step one, the same type of right.
Just as this Court has said that the widow and children exercise the same right that the author have if he dies (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: And that -- that so even though the author died prior to the beginning of the 28th year

turn.speaker: milton_a_rudin
turn.label: Mr. Milton A. Rudin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: And that was the situation in the Fox case.
So, something did survive through the executor.

turn.speaker: milton_a_rudin
turn.label: Mr. Milton A. Rudin
turn.text: Yes.
That's right.
If something survived to the author in a way --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Now, then --

turn.speaker: milton_a_rudin
turn.label: Mr. Milton A. Rudin
turn.text: -- he could exercise it prior to his death, the power of appointment.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Then does an executor at least normally take assets in his hands subject to valid contracts made with the testator?

turn.speaker: milton_a_rudin
turn.label: Mr. Milton A. Rudin
turn.text: Yes.
That's a true statement of general law.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Now, does that apply to copyrights, I don't know?

turn.speaker: milton_a_rudin
turn.label: Mr. Milton A. Rudin
turn.text: It would apply to copyrights if that was the type of contract involved here, Your Honor, but it was not.
If he had made a contract about the balance of the original term and the executor took it in the same manner he took Black Acre, the executor would be bound by it.

But what he had, what the author had was a power of appointment and our basic position is that the petitioner here by the bargain for nor obtained the -- that right but he -- that his assignment doesn't carry with it, he didn't bargain for it when he obtained -- obtained it.
He might have gotten it but perhaps if he appointed out for the man, he might have given him more than $1000 but he didn't buy that right.
And it's a separate and independent right, this is a case where an executor exercises the power of appointment and it's not the question of a divulsion of property that the man own.
This is after all a franchise, a grant by Congress which comes into being after the man dies and that's our position.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It is fair to say, Mr. Rudin, if not, tell me so that the basic difference between you and -- and your brother forgetting about the terms of this particular instrument and forgetting about that -- that question.

turn.speaker: milton_a_rudin
turn.label: Mr. Milton A. Rudin
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Is that a -- is that a fair basic statement of the difference between --

turn.speaker: milton_a_rudin
turn.label: Mr. Milton A. Rudin
turn.text: It's a very short statement of it, yes.I -- I believe that sir.
It's fair because -- and I think the proof of that is in the (Inaudible) case proof of support of our position.

The Court said he left a will and that's the intention that goes to the carry and the administrator would -- will attach, I'd like to --

turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart

turn.speaker: milton_a_rudin
turn.label: Mr. Milton A. Rudin
turn.text: -- apply that thing and turn it over to his town (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The question isn't whether you or Mr. Abeles -- or you and Mr. Abeles' view what an executor is.

The question is when you use a technical term like “executor”, what lawyers who used it means by an “executor”, then you will know that the notion of an executor and what the estate is called the “universitas”.
He has whatever the -- for the left.

Even your case of a power of appointment is not outside of that because he has that something called he could make a disposition on his death and there is no -- there's no immaterial moment there between the death of the executor and -- between the death of the testator and the executor.
He just slips into those shoes and those shoes or whatever the shoes are, I don't -- I'm not saying now, what the shoes are.
It depends what the shoes are then he slips into it.

turn.speaker: milton_a_rudin
turn.label: Mr. Milton A. Rudin
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And you have to decide what the shoes are and if you change the figure if there's a -- if -- if he has something which has disposable monetary value, then he can take care of it by his will.

turn.speaker: milton_a_rudin
turn.label: Mr. Milton A. Rudin
turn.text: My time is up and I would love to say further except I might just briefly say an executor does have rights under the Federal Employers Liability Act to cause of action.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: He -- he has -- sure he has but he --

turn.text: Might I respect to state (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: julian_t_abeles

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: No, no indeed you have more time -- yes.

turn.label: Mr. Julian T. Abeles

I respectfully --

(Voice Overlap)

Now, (Inaudible) the Court decide that it was not.
Thank you so much.

turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, may I ask you what your position means that your assignment would also cutoff the next of kin had there been no will?

You see, we protect our self --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, I --

turn.speaker: julian_t_abeles
turn.label: Mr. Julian T. Abeles
turn.text: But if I didn't get definitely so.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Suppose you had not had one, the man had died without a will.

turn.speaker: julian_t_abeles
turn.label: Mr. Julian T. Abeles

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Would not be good?

turn.label: Mr. Julian T. Abeles
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Why?

turn.label: Mr. Julian T. Abeles
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And also the statute says that he makes a will it's --

turn.speaker: julian_t_abeles
turn.label: Mr. Julian T. Abeles
turn.text: But I still --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- his executor gets it?

turn.label: Mr. Julian T. Abeles

turn.text: But the executor --

turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black

turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, that's while you were --

turn.label: Mr. Julian T. Abeles
turn.text: That's the reason I got it from the --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But if he does make a -- but if he does make a will, then it's no good.

turn.speaker: julian_t_abeles
turn.label: Mr. Julian T. Abeles
turn.text: The assignment for the next of kin, correct.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, I'm -- the -- I'm not talking about next of kin he does make a will and decides he wants to give it to the next of kin and somebody else.

turn.speaker: julian_t_abeles
turn.label: Mr. Julian T. Abeles
turn.text: Yes.

Of course you see as this Court said if I may respectfully say so, that if he has no wife and child he has a power, see, to designate by will, the executor apply for the renewal which of course would be for the purpose affecting the author's disposition thereof.
That's the way it is done.
If it intended, if the statute intended, may I say, that it should only be applied -- it should only apply for beneficiaries undergo it until he said so.
Instead of saying, he didn't leave a will or to have to save us if I might respectfully say so, if -- if there's no beneficiaries this is -- it is not disposed at the beneficiaries.
That's all just that same --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well there are many -- many ways they could have made it clear.

turn.speaker: julian_t_abeles
turn.label: Mr. Julian T. Abeles
turn.text: That's true --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But if --

turn.speaker: julian_t_abeles
turn.label: Mr. Julian T. Abeles
turn.text: And I think -- I think --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I -- I understand that here you say that in the first place, it would go to the widow and the children.

turn.speaker: julian_t_abeles
turn.label: Mr. Julian T. Abeles
turn.text: Definitely.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: No assignment could cut it off?

turn.speaker: julian_t_abeles
turn.label: Mr. Julian T. Abeles
turn.text: Definitely.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The next class they make is an executor.

turn.speaker: julian_t_abeles
turn.label: Mr. Julian T. Abeles
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You say that that is cutoff by society.

turn.speaker: julian_t_abeles
turn.label: Mr. Julian T. Abeles
turn.text: Cutoff badly, sir?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: No, by your assignment to you.

turn.speaker: julian_t_abeles
turn.label: Mr. Julian T. Abeles
turn.text: No.
No, I said -- well, put up with other way, if you don't mind.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, does the -- is the will any good does -- does anybody get anything from it?

turn.speaker: julian_t_abeles
turn.label: Mr. Julian T. Abeles
turn.text: Yes.
We (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The point of assignment you speak of.

turn.speaker: julian_t_abeles
turn.label: Mr. Julian T. Abeles
turn.text: Yes we do because if it wasn't for the will, we wouldn't get it by appointing the executor, he really effectuates the disposition to us through the executor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But even though he didn't try to.

turn.speaker: julian_t_abeles
turn.label: Mr. Julian T. Abeles
turn.text: I don't know if he did or didn't.
So, he didn't make a specific requirement.

turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black

turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Alright.
Then the second class is the executor.
Now, the third class which comes even after that is why they have no will?

turn.speaker: julian_t_abeles
turn.label: Mr. Julian T. Abeles
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you say that your assignment is no good against him?

turn.speaker: julian_t_abeles
turn.label: Mr. Julian T. Abeles
turn.text: If there's no will, that's correct.

turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Now then, let me ask you if I may sir.

turn.speaker: julian_t_abeles
turn.label: Mr. Julian T. Abeles
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: I want to get back to this administrator business.

turn.label: Mr. Julian T. Abeles
turn.text: Well, I -- the Court could leave him.

I -- I feel this way, I'm absolutely --

turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: You have to take it in a way --

turn.speaker: julian_t_abeles
turn.label: Mr. Julian T. Abeles
turn.text: I am.

turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker

turn.text: I understand that, sir.
